entry.title: Atypical Category Learning in Poor Comprehenders

link.title: Atypical Category Learning in Poor Comprehenders

entry.content:
Time Period: Fall 2014 - Fall 2018

Languages Used: R

Statistical Methods: Linear mixed-effects modeling

This project investigated how adolescents with poor reading comprehension ability learn new categories. I designed the experiment and the data analysis. We found that poor comprehenders exhibit performance consistent with poor cognitive flexibility – once they settle on a learning strategy, they tend to stick with that strategy even if it is suboptimal.

All of the data and code for this project is hosted on GitHub. For a walkthrough of the analysis, see the markdown file.

Output

In progress: A manuscript detailing this study is currently under review at Scientific Studies of Reading.

October, 2016: My master’s thesis reports results from a version of this task done on typically-developing undergraduate students.

April, 2016: Characterizing novel concept learning in poor comprehenders. Poster presented at the 7th University of Connecticut Language Festival, Storrs, CT.

entry.title: Definition of Poor Comprehenders
entry.content:
Time Period: Spring 2016 - present

Languages Used: R

Statistical Methods: Linear regression, multiple imputation (mice and missForest packages)

In this project, we investigated regression-based methods for classifying individuals with different reading profiles. We used these classifications to look at group differences in brain structure.

I used R to run a variety of regression models to select groups and test for group effects in brain structure. I learned how to efficiently run many models and create easily readable output.

All of the data and code for this project is hosted on GitHub.

Output

November, 2017: Structural brain differences in good and poor comprehenders identified through a regression-based quantitative method. Poster presented at the 9th Annual Meeting of the Society for the Neurobiology of Language, Baltimore, MD.

April, 2016: Definition of poor comprehenders. Poster presented at the 7th University of Connecticut Language Festival, Storrs, CT.

entry.title: CARAT
entry.content:
Time Period: Fall 2017 - Spring 2018

Languages Used: Python, Shell

CARAT is a study looking at the neural bases of facial emotion perception, led by Ross Buck.

I created a processing pipeline for functional neuroimaging data, including image processing using AFNI, data reshaping and cleaning in Python, and batch processing with shell scripting.

Output

You can view code and extensive documentation for this project on Github.
